Purpose

HMB (Heavy Menstrual Bleeding) is a common problem affecting women throughout their reproductive years. In the majority of cases, no underlying pathology is found and the condition responds well to simple treatments. Ensuring that women are investigated appropriately is essential, as is a logical, step-wise approach to treatment.
This guideline is intended to guide those working in both primary and secondary care to ensure that women are optimally assessed, investigated and treated.
Equality and Diversity
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to provision of a service that is fair, accessible, and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix D)
Scope
This guideline is an addition to and should be read in conjunction with the NICE guideline on Heavy Menstrual Bleeding.
Definition of Heavy Menstrual Bleeding
Excessive menstrual blood loss interfering with physical, emotional, social and material quality of life.
Measuring menstrual loss is not routinely recommended. Diagnosis should be based on the woman's perception of menstrual loss and the degree to which it affects her quality of life.
History, examination and investigations
History taking

To cover the nature of the bleeding, related symptoms such as pain, impact on quality of life, previous treatments tried and co-morbidities. If a woman has a history of Heavy Menstrual Bleeding without other related symptoms, consider pharmacological treatment without carrying out a physical examination unless the treatment chosen is the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG IUS).
Features suggestive of structural/histological abnormalities include:
Intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding;
Pelvic pain;
Pressure symptoms.
Examine prior to:
Insertion of LNG IUS;
Investigations for suspected structural/histological abnormalities.
Blood tests:
Full blood count in all women with HMB;
Clotting screen for those with HMB since menarche or personal/family history suggestive of clotting disorder;
Thyroid function tests only if other signs and symptoms of thyroid disease.
USS (Ultrasound Screening) Imaging:
Uterus palpable per abdomen
VE (vaginal examination) reveals pelvic mass of uncertain origin
Pharmaceutical treatment fails
Intermenstrual bleeding or erratic menstrual cycle
Patient build making clinical assessment difficult
Endometrial Biopsy:
To exclude endometrial cancer or atypical hyperplasia;
Persistent inter-menstrual bleeding;
Women > 45 years of age;
Ineffective treatment/treatment failure.
Other Investigations:

Hysteroscopy should be used for diagnostic purposes when ultrasound is inconclusive and in many cases can be done as an outpatient procedure. Outpatient hysteroscopy guidance is detailed in a separate MEHT document.
Dilatation & Curettage (D & C) alone should not be used as an investigative tool
Pharmaceutical Treatment
If history does not suggest structural or histological abnormality, then st line treatment may be commenced without further investigation.
Consider pharmaceutical treatment as st line if, after investigation, no structural or histological abnormality is found, or if fibroids less than 3cm not distorting the cavity.
If hormonal treatment is not acceptable (e.g. those wishing to avoid contraception) then use Tranexamic 1 gm TDS +/- Mefenamic acid 500 mg TDS orally.
If either hormonal or non-hormonal treatments are acceptable then consider, in this order:
Mirena IUS providing at least 12 months use is anticipated;
Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) or Tranexamic acid/Mefenamic acid;
Progestogen only pills such as Cerazette (Cerelle) or Noriday
Mefenamic acid should be added to Tranexamic acid if dysmenorrhoea is a problem.
Choice of COCP:
Usually standard dose oestrogen with nd generation progestagen is st line: e.g. Microgynon  or Loestrin 30;
Can use low dose oestrogen if risk factors for cardiovascular disease: e.g. Gedarel 20/150 or Millinette 20/75;
Phasic preparations can be used if breakthrough bleeding is problematic. e.g. TriRegol or Logynon;

Qlaira is a phasic preparation containing oestradiol valerate rather than ethinyloestradiol. It is licensed both for HMB and as a contraceptive, with evidence that withdrawal bleeding is both shorter and lighter.
Depo-provera or the progesterone-only implant (Nexplanon) are not licensed for HMB, however reduction in menstrual flow or amenorrhoea with continued use is widely reported.
Continue to use Mefenamic/Tranexamic acid as long as beneficial but stop using if no benefit after 3 cycles.
If starting treatment prior to completing investigations, use Tranexamic acid +/- Mefenamic acid.
If st line pharmaceutical treatment has failed can try other pharmaceutical methods before resorting to surgery

GnRH analogues (with add back HRT) can be used prior to surgery or when all other treatment for uterine fibroids are contraindicated or when a patient is suitable for conservative management of uterine fibroids. Those women in the peri-menopausal age group would be most suitable for this treatment regimen.
Do not use danazol routinely in HMB or luteal phase-only progestogens
Surgical Treatment
Endometrial ablation
Consider if HMB having severe effect on quality of life and no desire to conceive in
future;
May be offered as an initial treatment or after failed medical treatment;
Can be done in the presence of small (< 3cm) intramural uterine fibroids;

In women with a history of Caesarean section, consideration should be given to performing an ultrasound with subsequent assessment of myometrial thickness at the level of the scar ‘niche'. If this thickness is less than 8mm, the risk of thermal injury to nearby structures, e.g. the bladder, may be increased;
Advise to avoid subsequent pregnancy and use contraception.
Fibroid Surgery
If large fibroids, HMB and other significant symptoms e.g. dysmenorrhoea or pressure symptoms, can use uterine artery embolisation (UAE) or surgery as st line;
UAE, trans-cervical resection of fibroids or abdominal myomectomy may allow preservation of fertility;
Prior to surgery or UAE do an ultrasound to assess size and location. If further detail required, proceed to MRI;
Consider pre-treatment with GnRH analogues for 3-4 months before myomectomy or hysterectomy where fibroids are enlarging or distorting the uterus.
Hysterectomy
Should not be used as st line treatment solely for HMB;
When done solely for heavy menstrual bleeding may only be done under threshold approval:
Consider when
Discuss risks and implications of hysterectomy including that there is a higher rate of operative complications when fibroids are present;
Discuss possible loss of ovarian function even if ovaries are retained at surgery
Individual assessment when deciding route:
st line surgical approach is usually vaginal, followed by total laparoscopic or abdominal depending on operator experience;
If need for oophorectomy at time of vaginal hysterectomy consider laparoscopic approach;
Do not remove healthy ovaries at hysterectomy but consider removing fallopian tubes to reduce the future risk of ovarian cancer development;

Some women have chronic pelvic pain or severe PMS and are offered GnRH analogues before hysterectomy to switch off ovarian function. If this provides significant symptom relief, then bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy should be considered after discussion with the patient regarding the pros and cons. The patient should also be counselled about the possible need for oestrogen replacement after surgical menopause.
Patient counselling
All women should be given information on potentially unwanted outcomes following both medical and surgical interventions for HMB. These are summarised in Appendix B.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be undertaken on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy. The Audit Lead in liaison with the Risk Management Group will identify a lead for the audit.
The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary
Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and
timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.

table_items.text: Potential unwanted outcomes experienced by some women (Common: 1 in 100 chance; less common: 1 in 1000 chance; rare: 1 in 10,000 chance; very rare: 1 in 100,000 chance).

Common: irregular bleeding that may last for over 6 months; hormone-related problems such as breast tenderness, acne or headaches, which, if present, are generally minor and transient. Less common: amenorrhoea. Rare: uterine perforation at the time of insertion.
Common: indigestion; diarrhoea. Rare: worsening of asthma in sensitive individuals; peptic ulcers with possible bleeding and peritonitis.
Common: mood changes; headaches; nausea; fluid retention; breast tenderness. Very rare: deep vein thrombosis; stroke; heart attacks.
Common: weight gain; bloating; breast tenderness; headaches; acne (but all are usually minor and transient). Rare: depression.

Common: weight gain; irregular bleeding; amenorrhoea; premenstrual-like syndrome (including bloating, fluid retention, breast tenderness). Less common: small loss of bone mineral density, largely recovered when treatment discontinued.
Common: menopausal-like symptoms (such as hot flushes, increased sweating, vaginal dryness). Less common: osteoporosis, particularly trabecular bone with longer than 6-months' use.

Common: vaginal discharge; increased period pain or cramping (even if no further bleeding); need for additional surgery. Less common: infection. Rare: perforation (but very rare with second generation techniques).

Common: persistent vaginal discharge; post-embolisation syndrome – pain, nausea, vomiting and fever (not involving hospitalisation). Less common: need for additional surgery; premature ovarian failure particularly in women over 45 years old; haematoma. Rare: haemorrhage; non-target embolisation causing tissue necrosis; infection causing septicaemia.
Less common: adhesions (which may lead to pain and/or impaired fertility); need for additional surgery; recurrence of fibroids; perforation (hysteroscopic route); infection. Rare: haemorrhage.

Common: infection. Less common: intraoperative haemorrhage; damage to other abdominal organs, such as the urinary tract or bowel; urinary dysfunction – frequent passing of urine and incontinence. Rare: thrombosis (DVT and clot on the lung). Very rare: death. (Complications are more likely when hysterectomy is performed in the presence of fibroids.)
